rule.name: Container Image - Package with Critical Severity CVEs
rule.logic: Package where scannedAsset.entityType in('KubernetesImage', 'ContainerRegistryImage', 'ShiftLeftImage', 'EcsImage') should not have severity='Critical'
rule.description: Container Image contains Package with Critical Severity CVEs
rule.remediation: Check the Remediation field on the Package. If there is a Remediation, upgrade the package to the recommended package version.

rule.name: AWS Workloads - Package with Critical Severity CVEs
rule.logic: Package where scannedAsset.entityType='Instance' should not have severity='Critical'
rule.description: Aws Instance contains Package with Critical Severity CVEs
rule.remediation: Check the Remediation field on the Package. If there is a Remediation, upgrade the package to the recommended package version.

rule.name: Azure Workloads - Package with Critical Severity CVEs
rule.logic: Package where scannedAsset.entityType in('FunctionApp', 'VirtualMachine') should not have severity='Critical'
rule.description: Azure Virtual Machine or Function App contains Package with Critical Severity CVEs
rule.remediation: Check the Remediation field on the Package. If there is a Remediation, upgrade the package to the recommended package version.

rule.name: Azure Workloads - Package with High Severity CVEs
rule.logic: Package where scannedAsset.entityType in('FunctionApp', 'VirtualMachine') should not have severity='High'
rule.description: Azure Virtual Machine or Function App contains Package with High Severity CVEs
rule.remediation: Check the Remediation field on the Package. If there is a Remediation, upgrade the package to the recommended package version.

rule.name: Container Image - Package with High Severity CVEs
rule.logic: Package where scannedAsset.entityType in('KubernetesImage', 'ContainerRegistryImage', 'ShiftLeftImage', 'EcsImage') should not have severity='High'
rule.description: Container Image contains Package with High Severity CVEs
rule.remediation: Check the Remediation field on the Package. If there is a Remediation, upgrade the package to the recommended package version.

rule.name: AWS Workloads - Malware
rule.description: AWS Instance contains malware (malicious IP, URL or file)
rule.remediation: Take proactive measures to thoroughly investigate and address the detected malware, and remove it from your application if necessary.

rule.name: Container Image - Malware
rule.logic: Malware where scannedAsset.entityType in('KubernetesImage', 'ContainerRegistryImage', 'ShiftLeftImage', 'EcsImage') should fail
rule.description: Container Image contains malware (malicious IP, URL or file)
rule.remediation: Take proactive measures to thoroughly investigate and address the detected malware, and remove it from your application if necessary.

rule.name: AWS Workloads - Package with High Severity CVEs
rule.logic: Package where scannedAsset.entityType='Instance' should not have severity='High'
rule.description: Aws Instance contains Package with High Severity CVEs
rule.remediation: Check the Remediation field on the Package. If there is a Remediation, upgrade the package to the recommended package version.

rule.name: Azure Workloads - Malware
rule.logic: Malware where scannedAsset.entityType in('FunctionApp', 'VirtualMachine') should fail
rule.description: Azure Virtual Machine or Function App contains malware (malicious IP, URL or file)
rule.remediation: Take proactive measures to thoroughly investigate and address the detected malware, and remove it from your application if necessary.

rule.name: Azure Workloads – Insecure Content
rule.logic: InsecureContent where scannedAsset.entityType in('FunctionApp', 'VirtualMachine') should fail
rule.description: Azure Virtual Machine or Function App contains insecure content (e.g., secrets or credentials)
rule.remediation: Conduct a comprehensive review of your application code to assess the nature of the identified data. Implement security measures to mitigate the risk associated with insecure content

rule.name: AWS Workloads – Insecure Content
rule.description: AWS Instance contains insecure content (e.g., secrets or credentials)
rule.remediation: Conduct a comprehensive review of your application code to assess the nature of the identified data. Implement security measures to mitigate the risk associated with insecure content

rule.name: Container Image – Insecure Content
rule.logic: InsecureContent where scannedAsset.entityType in('KubernetesImage', 'ContainerRegistryImage', 'ShiftLeftImage', 'EcsImage') should fail
rule.description: Container Image contains insecure content (e.g., secrets or credentials)
rule.remediation: Conduct a comprehensive review of your application code to assess the nature of the identified data. Implement security measures to mitigate the risk associated with insecure content

cves.description:
Issue summary: Applications performing certificate name checks (e.g., TLS
clients checking server certificates) may attempt to read an invalid memory
address resulting in abnormal termination of the application process.

Impact summary: Abnormal termination of an application can a cause a denial of
service.

Applications performing certificate name checks (e.g., TLS clients checking
server certificates) may attempt to read an invalid memory address when
comparing the expected name with an `otherName` subject alternative name of an
X.509 certificate. This may result in an exception that terminates the
application program.

Note that basic certificate chain validation (signatures, dates, ...) is not
affected, the denial of service can occur only when the application also
specifies an expected DNS name, Email address or IP address.

TLS servers rarely solicit client certificates, and even when they do, they
generally don't perform a name check against a reference identifier (expected
identity), but rather extract the presented identity after checking the
certificate chain.  So TLS servers are generally not affected and the severity
of the issue is Moderate.

The FIPS modules in 3.3, 3.2, 3.1 and 3.0 are not affected by this issue.

Validating the order of the public keys in the Diffie-Hellman Key Agreement Protocol, when an approved safe prime is used, allows remote attackers (from the client side) to trigger unnecessarily expensive server-side DHE modular-exponentiation calculations. The client may cause asymmetric resource consumption. The basic attack scenario is that the client must claim that it can only communicate with DHE, and the server must be configured to allow DHE and validate the order of the public key.

relatedCves.description:
Issue summary: Applications performing certificate name checks (e.g., TLS
clients checking server certificates) may attempt to read an invalid memory
address resulting in abnormal termination of the application process.

Impact summary: Abnormal termination of an application can a cause a denial of
service.

Applications performing certificate name checks (e.g., TLS clients checking
server certificates) may attempt to read an invalid memory address when
comparing the expected name with an `otherName` subject alternative name of an
X.509 certificate. This may result in an exception that terminates the
application program.

Note that basic certificate chain validation (signatures, dates, ...) is not
affected, the denial of service can occur only when the application also
specifies an expected DNS name, Email address or IP address.

TLS servers rarely solicit client certificates, and even when they do, they
generally don't perform a name check against a reference identifier (expected
identity), but rather extract the presented identity after checking the
certificate chain.  So TLS servers are generally not affected and the severity
of the issue is Moderate.

The FIPS modules in 3.3, 3.2, 3.1 and 3.0 are not affected by this issue.

Validating the order of the public keys in the Diffie-Hellman Key Agreement Protocol, when an approved safe prime is used, allows remote attackers (from the client side) to trigger unnecessarily expensive server-side DHE modular-exponentiation calculations. The client may cause asymmetric resource consumption. The basic attack scenario is that the client must claim that it can only communicate with DHE, and the server must be configured to allow DHE and validate the order of the public key.

package.name: libssl3t64
package.description: Package contains 2 CVEs: 0 Critical, 0 High, 2 Medium, 0 Low, 0 Unknown.

cves.description: A timing-based side-channel flaw was found in libgcrypt's RSA implementation. This issue may allow a remote attacker to initiate a Bleichenbacher-style attack, which can lead to the decryption of RSA ciphertexts.

relatedCves.description: A timing-based side-channel flaw was found in libgcrypt's RSA implementation. This issue may allow a remote attacker to initiate a Bleichenbacher-style attack, which can lead to the decryption of RSA ciphertexts.

package.name: libgcrypt20
package.description: Package contains 1 CVEs: 0 Critical, 0 High, 1 Medium, 0 Low, 0 Unknown.

cves.description: Integer overflow vulnerability in pcre2test before 10.41 allows attackers to cause a denial of service or other unspecified impacts via negative input.

relatedCves.description: Integer overflow vulnerability in pcre2test before 10.41 allows attackers to cause a denial of service or other unspecified impacts via negative input.

package.name: libpcre2-8-0
package.description: Package contains 1 CVEs: 0 Critical, 0 High, 0 Medium, 1 Low, 0 Unknown.

cves.description: GnuPG can be made to spin on a relatively small input by (for example) crafting a public key with thousands of signatures attached, compressed down to just a few KB.

relatedCves.description: GnuPG can be made to spin on a relatively small input by (for example) crafting a public key with thousands of signatures attached, compressed down to just a few KB.

package.name: gpgv
package.description: Package contains 1 CVEs: 0 Critical, 0 High, 0 Medium, 1 Low, 0 Unknown.

cves.description: chroot in GNU coreutils, when used with --userspec, allows local users to escape to the parent session via a crafted TIOCSTI ioctl call, which pushes characters to the terminal's input buffer.

relatedCves.description: chroot in GNU coreutils, when used with --userspec, allows local users to escape to the parent session via a crafted TIOCSTI ioctl call, which pushes characters to the terminal's input buffer.

package.name: coreutils
package.description: Package contains 1 CVEs: 0 Critical, 0 High, 0 Medium, 1 Low, 0 Unknown.

imageScan.description:
Vulnerabilities: 6 CVEs, 0 malicious URLs, 0 malicious IPs, 0 malicious files, 0 insecure content. 
By severity: 0 critical, 0 high, 3 medium, 3 low, 0 unknown.
imageScan.remediation:
Upgrade 1 packages with CVEs (fix 1/6 findings)

CVEs:
libssl3t64@3.0.13-0ubuntu3.2 (deb): Upgrade to 3.0.13-0ubuntu3.4 (fixes CVE-2024-6119 (Medium))


CVEs Without Remediation:
CVE-2024-41996 (Medium), CVE-2024-2236 (Medium), CVE-2022-41409 (Low), CVE-2022-3219 (Low), CVE-2016-2781 (Low)
